what: To define a data frame, use the following steps:
title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: Define vectors columns data frame. Note: vector length. Suppose x, y, z three columns data frame. Combine columns form data frame command data_frame(,b,c).
code: library(generatervis) ## basic example code x <- c(3,5,9,7) y <- c("place_1","place_2","place_3","place_4") z <- c("x1","x2","x3","x4") df <- data_frame(x,y,z) print(df) #>   x       y  z #> 1 3 place_1 x1 #> 2 5 place_2 x2 #> 3 9 place_3 x3 #> 4 7 place_4 x4

what: Function to clean the data file — clean
title: Function to clean the data file — clean
text: Function clean data file

title: Function to clean the data file — clean
Function to clean the data file — clean
text: x integer. y integer.

title: Function to clean the data file — clean
text: modified data frame.

title: Function to clean the data file — clean

what: Create an empty .fastq file using patient ID — create_empty_fastq
title: Create an empty .fastq file using patient ID — create_empty_fastq
text: function creates empty FASTQ file specified patient ID. file contain single entry patient ID sequence identifier. sequence quality scores empty

title: Create an empty .fastq file using patient ID — create_empty_fastq
Create an empty .fastq file using patient ID — create_empty_fastq
text: patient_id character vector representing patient IDs. output_dir character string specifying directory FASTQ file saved. Default current working directory.

title: Create an empty .fastq file using patient ID — create_empty_fastq
text: function constructs FASTQ file following format: Line 1: Sequence ID (e.g., @patient_id) Line 2: Empty sequence Line 3: Separator (e.g., +) Line 4: Empty quality scores

title: Create an empty .fastq file using patient ID — create_empty_fastq
code: # Create an empty FASTQ file for patient ID "patient_123"  create_empty_fastq("patient_123") #> Empty FASTQ file created at: ./patient_123.fastq  # Create an empty FASTQ file for patient ID "patient_456" in a specific directory  create_empty_fastq("patient_456", output_dir = ".") #> Empty FASTQ file created at: ./patient_456.fastq

title: Title — data_frame
text: Title

title: Title — data_frame
Title — data_frame
text: x Column 1 data frame y Column 2 data frame z Column 3 data frame

title: Title — data_frame
text: data frame

title: Title — data_frame
code: x <- c("a","p") y <- c(12.56,38) z <- c("abc","pqr") data_frame(x, y, z) #>   x     y   z #> 1 a 12.56 abc #> 2 p 38.00 pqr

what: Function to fill a FASTQ file with random reads — fill_fastq
title: Function to fill a FASTQ file with random reads — fill_fastq
text: function populates FASTQ file random reads given patient ID. function first creates empty FASTQ file using patient ID, generates specified number random reads, writes file.

title: Function to fill a FASTQ file with random reads — fill_fastq
Function to fill a FASTQ file with random reads — fill_fastq
text: patient_id character string representing patient ID. output_dir character string specifying directory FASTQ file saved. Default current working directory. n integer specifying number reads generate. read_length integer specifying length read. Default 8. multiple 4.

title: Function to fill a FASTQ file with random reads — fill_fastq
text: function first checks FASTQ file already exists. , appends new reads existing file. , creates new file. generated reads FASTQ format, consists four lines per read: Line 1: Sequence identifier (e.g., @patient_id_read1) Line 2: Random DNA sequence Line 3: Separator (e.g., +) Line 4: Quality scores

title: Function to fill a FASTQ file with random reads — fill_fastq
code: # Fill a FASTQ file for patient ID "patient_123" with 2 reads of length 8 fill_fastq("patient_123",output_dir = ".", n = 2, read_length = 8) #> File already exists. Appending reads to the existing file. #> Populated ./patient_123.fastq with 2 reads.

what: Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
title: Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
text: function generates specified number random reads FASTQ format. read consists sequence identifier, random DNA sequence, separator line, quality scores.

title: Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
text: patient_id character string representing patient ID. n integer specifying number reads generate. read_length integer specifying length read. Default 8. multiple 4.

title: Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
text: character vector containing generated FASTQ lines.

title: Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
text: function generates random DNA sequences using nucleotides , T, G, C. quality scores represented ASCII characters, '' indicating high quality. output formatted FASTQ file, consists four lines per read: Line 1: Sequence identifier (e.g., @patient_id_read1) Line 2: Random DNA sequence Line 3: Separator (e.g., +) Line 4: Quality scores @seealso  create_empty_fastq creating empty FASTQ file.

title: Function to generate a random sample of reads in FASTQ format — rreads
code: # Generate 5 random reads for patient ID "patient_123" rreads("patient_123", n = 5) #>  [1] "@patient_123_read1" "GATTGGTG"           "+"                  #>  [4] "IIIIIIII"           "@patient_123_read2" "AACATTGG"           #>  [7] "+"                  "IIIIIIII"           "@patient_123_read3" #> [10] "CCTGATGG"           "+"                  "IIIIIIII"           #> [13] "@patient_123_read4" "CATATGTC"           "+"                  #> [16] "IIIIIIII"           "@patient_123_read5" "ATACCTGA"           #> [19] "+"                  "IIIIIIII"           # Generate 10 random reads for patient ID "patient_456" with a read length of 10 rreads("patient_456", n = 10, read_length = 10) #>  [1] "@patient_456_read1"  "TTGTAAGTAC"          "+"                   #>  [4] "IIIIIIIIII"          "@patient_456_read2"  "ACCGCCCGTG"          #>  [7] "+"                   "IIIIIIIIII"          "@patient_456_read3"  #> [10] "TGTGTCTAGT"          "+"                   "IIIIIIIIII"          #> [13] "@patient_456_read4"  "TGATCCACAG"          "+"                   #> [16] "IIIIIIIIII"          "@patient_456_read5"  "CTATTTGCTC"          #> [19] "+"                   "IIIIIIIIII"          "@patient_456_read6"  #> [22] "TTAGGCAAAA"          "+"                   "IIIIIIIIII"          #> [25] "@patient_456_read7"  "TAAATCAGGA"          "+"                   #> [28] "IIIIIIIIII"          "@patient_456_read8"  "CGGCTCAGAG"          #> [31] "+"                   "IIIIIIIIII"          "@patient_456_read9"  #> [34] "ATAAAAGATG"          "+"                   "IIIIIIIIII"          #> [37] "@patient_456_read10" "CGCTATTGCG"          "+"                   #> [40] "IIIIIIIIII"
